cQaU8tBDmtED8-EaBE2JNg.text: Dinner for two cost nearly the same as my mortgage.  ($850, with ONE wine pairing)   Terribly overpriced, and in my mind a huge disappointment.  I've had many fine dining experiences, and this one did not measure up nearly to what I've had in the past.  I left this experience with regret and wishing I had made a different decision for my birthday dinner

YGyz3tyuf9UsuKAoLyJhbA.text: Unbelievable.  I couldn't even imagine food this good.  My previous favorite was in Napa.  Each course was just as amazing as the last.  The little bread cart was cute and the really small rolls were my favorite.  Never thought mashed potatoes could be that good!

yODi70rvTALyKDUBBAjgIg.text: What a delightful experience coming here tonight.  I was by myself, and wanted an early light dinner and was happy with my choices.  The staff was very attentive and the food was delicious.   My first experience at a 3 star Michelin restaurant.

Kg-Rh_-w8LvxgypIGH0srQ.text: The one thing I love about vegas is the FOOD and entertainment! You get the best of everything all conveniently located in walking distance on the strip 24/7. We got tickets to the KA show which is located inside MGM. Since we are both food lovers and fans of CHEF OF THE CENTURY Joel Robuchon, he decided to treat us to this restaurant since it was located right next door to the KA Theater. FYI: we made reservations way in advance (about a month) it books up quick  We decided to do the Course A Menus in addition to extra a la carte plates off the menu. Total was a little over $400 w/ tax & tip, but totally worth it!! (Yes you get charged for water)  We were lucky to get close seating so that we could see the open kitchen. I loved watching the chefs do their thing live. Felt like I was on Master chef being one of the judges hehe. The setting is very intimate w/ dim lit lights and red/black color theme. Our waiter was very professional and had great recommendations. We got started off w/ complimentary bread basket and butter. THAT BUTTER WOW not sure if it's house made, but it is some bomb ass butter w/ their bread basket (ate 2 baskets of it!)  For course A you get Amuse-Bouche, 2 appetizers, 1 main course, and 1 dessert.  Amuse Bouche - It was Foie Gras parfait w/ port wine & parmesan foam. Goodness it was sooo rich I almost choked trying to take it all in one shot. The foie gras is very distinct as I haven't had it before in CA. Very great opener to start our meal  Les Langoustine - HOLY CRAP I wish I ordered double of this. Don't you just love french names for food? They always sound so appealing and the langoustine dish here lived up to its name. It basically was like a tempura deep fried lobster, but the outside wasn't oily at all! It was crispy and had the perfect crunch. Incredible, meaty, juicy langoustine  La Fromage - Cheese plate. If you're a fan of cheese & wine make sure u order this. It was a la carte, but all the cheeses were delish! YES even the blue cheese (We have never been a fan of blue cheese, but loved it here)  Le Caille - Free range foie gras stuffed quail w/ mashed potatoes. OMG the mashed potatoes here are to die for, sooo buttery. The stuffed quail was by far the best I've had. Presentation was gorgeous. Definitely try this dish  Lobster gnocchi - The gnocchi was a bit undercooked and they were nice enough to offer us another dish, but we were running short on time for the Ka Show so instead they comped us a dish :) Customer service at its finest! The sauce and lobster were superb, if only the gnocchi wasn't undercooked :(  Kampachi - FRESH and neatly presented. Very light tasting  Cod - Small portion, but very filling. I felt that the fish was overcooked. However, it could just have been my fault for comparing it to sea bass which is usually rich & buttery in texture anyway.  La Hampe - Hangar steak med rare. After reading some of the reviews we ordered this dish a la carte and it was SOOOOO GOOD. Cooked perfectly med rare, was tender and melted in my mouth. Couldn't have asked for a more beautiful meat dish  La Framboise - ice cream w/ fresh berries dessert. A work of art for sure that I didn't even know where to start digging in. The berries were sweet & fresh, ice cream was rich, creamy, and refreshing.  Souffle - Took a while 'cause souffle takes time to rise. Our waiter was kind enough to make sure we got it fast enough so that we could make it on time for our show! It came out rising high and this delicate dessert was delicious.  There were more plates, but I can't remember the name of each dish since we ate here a while back in October. However, every dish was an art! I can't wait to come back and try the tasting menu next door. I love that the menu is seasonal and changes, that's the art & beauty of fancy restaurants like Joel Robuchon's.

hAvHIRWbEB2hPyZPtMAqCg.text: We did the Discovery Menu in August 2017 and it blew us away. Every course was beautifully presented and the flavors were incredible. Each course was paced well and we were stuffed by the 9th course. We had a great view of all the chefs preparing each course and I would absolutely come back and do the exact same menu over and over. Absolutely worth the price!

fPvikyzjQ_koB8quzohPBw.text: There are actually two Restaurants in Vegas owned by this chef, whom I believe to be at this time one of the greatest chefs of our time!  The upscale fine dining from the same Chef located next door, which you may need at least 6 months to a year to make a reservation.  This one is a smaller upscaled one, which is an experience all in itself. Reservations are needed, but you can be lucky enough to get seated if cancellations or space is available! Don't feel like the bar seating is demeaning in anyway, on the contrary, that's where you will be front and center where the action happens!!! There are also tables along the wall for bigger groups!   If you normally read my reviews, you know I really tell you like it is, and this one my fellow Yelpers is one of those don't want to miss dinners and experiences! Very reasonable within the menu, with choice of meals/apps chosen from their menu. The Chef and staff totally work with you should you have tickets for a concert or an event!  I really couldn't find one darn thing wrong with this place! Can't wait to go back!!

photos.caption: Photo of L'Atelier de Joël Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Not only is the presentation superb, but the food quality is excellent!

1Bf0WYDbLQFDiGYP2QB8-Q.text: Another Michelin star adventure on my list, and a worthy one at that!   We were a little worried that the transition of executive chefs would hinder our experience but I am happy to say that it did not. We loved the atmosphere, akin to a hip sushi bar, yet serving elegant upscale French cuisine. We found this setting allowed for a more comfortable and casual experience as well as encouraging more interaction with our server to discuss the menu at length.   We found the wine list to be slightly overpriced with a bottle of Quintessa that may run $310 or so at other restaurants to be $385 here, and Cade which may run $90 elsewhere to be around $120 here, but then again it's Vegas and expensive drinks are the name of the game.   The food however was fairly priced for the amazing experience. We found the flavors to be exquisite, and the plating was phenomenal. Since we were at the bar we would watch with amazement as the cooks would spend 5 minutes plating our dishes with tweezers. Only for us to devour them in half the time, using bread to sop up any leftover sauce and returning a clean plate.   While they would incorporate so many inventive flavors in many of the dishes, they also know when to back off and let the main ingredient shine, for example the Iberico Ham was presented very simply with only some small crostini with diced tomato as an accompaniment. It's an amazing thing to eat, better then any prosciutto and was best left alone.     We also experienced the Veal Sweetbreads, and this dish has scared me in the past as I have never enjoyed it, until now. This time it was done right and is worth giving a shot!

jJu_7_cYv_gP9hUtlrYZqQ.text: Originally my bf made the reservation for the Saturday night 9:00PM because that's the only time available. However, earlier the day when we passed by the restaurant, we asked if there's any time earlier and they updated our reservation to 7:30PM, which is nice so we won't be starving badly.  The restaurant is small... Most of customers were seated by the bar so everyone can see the activities in the kitchen. But during the entire dining time, there's always empty seats so it seems not too popular by its pricing?  We decided to order one of menu A $108.00 with Le Foie Gras (+$15.00), Le Mais, Le Veau, and Les Tartes, plus Les Caille in main course size $45.00.  Bread: They offer free and refillable breads for customers. As all others mentioned before, if this is freshly baked not served cold it would be wonderful.  Amuse-Bouche: It consisted of a parmigiano reggiano foam on top, port wine reduction in the middle, and foie gras mousse on the bottom. To be honest I couldn't really tell what exactly I was eating if no one explain to me. The combination of these ingredients was amazing though!  Le Mais: Polenta was fried just right not oily... Shaved Iberico Ham was pretty strong in flavor but not in salty way.   Le Foie Gras: Since foie gras is abandoned in California, I'd like to eat any dish with it and of course I'll have to order it! We ordered the seared foie gras and it was wonderful... except it contained lots of oil which isn't good for your health haha! You can see all the oil on the plate after you cut the foie gras... Also the fruit they served with was peach but it's kind of too sweet to eat with foie gras... For me I'd rather to eat foie gras alone.  Les Caille: This is one of the famous dish here and originally it's included in the set menu but it no longer is so we ordered it separately. Unfortunately, maybe I had too high expectation but this dish wasn't really amazed me! The description said 'quail filled with foie gras' but I barely tasted foie gras; Meat part is a bit dry or maybe quail was supposed to be drier than other kind of meat? Potato puree was also very famous here... The even provided a separated bowls for some extra puree. It's tasty but for some reason I feel it's sweet in taste for me. Maybe they purposely made it that way?  Le Veau: This is not on their regular menu that's why I chose it. The veal breast is soft and tender... but flavor wise it's a bit plain and make you feel you can make this at home too. Zucchini saltimbocca wasn't my kind of flavor but my bf loved it.  Les Tartes: It took long time for the restaurant to serve this dessert, but it's totally worth it. When it was served, almost everyone besides us were looking at it because there were 5 tarts in the plate, makes this dessert pretty big in portion. We got mango, chocolate, raspberry, lemon and one other flavor, all delicious and not too sweet. They constantly change tart flavors and luckily we loved the ones they served this time.  Madeleine: The restaurant also served its own dessert Madeleine, and it tasted totally different from the one from Costco. It reminded me of the cakes from my own country Taiwan, which is amazing because it isn't something common in the USA. It was fresh and tasty as well!  Overall it was an exceptional experience dining here. Service was good except they didn't really pour water as often as they should... For some reason none of the dish was salty but we drank a lot more water than usual that's why I noticed.

mB58oeHxhwnXEnygDNeWiQ.text: I had the opportunity to dine at L'atelier Joel Robuchon on September 4th. The entire experience was sublime from start to finish, from the feast for the eyes as I watched my dishes being prepared, to the feast for my mouth served in the form of the Seasonal Discovery menu with premium wine pairing.  Patrick started off my experience with the Pamplemousse cocktail. I'm not normally much for rye whiskey, but damn it if this wasn't delightful. There was a slight hiccup with the pacing of the wine pairing, but it resolved by the 3rd course. I just had to gulp my Pamplemousse a little quicker than I would have liked.   First served was the foie gras parfait with parmesan emulsion, served with a generous pour of Laurent-Perrier Ultra Brut. The crisp, dry champagne cut through the richness of the foie gras beautifully. The foie gras parfait was somehow light despite the richness, and Patrick informed me it was due to using eggs to "fluff up" the dish.  Next was the tuna tartare with avocado and virgin olive oil. I added the Osetra caviar supplement because why not? I had a harder time with this dish. The champagne was delicious against the caviar, but I had difficulty with the texture of the tartare. There was nothing wrong with the preparation, just not to my personal liking. The caviar saved it for me.  A new pour followed the tartare, a delicious, rich pinot gris that I need to have in my life on a more regular basis. It was accompanied by a tomato gazpacho with burrata cheese and house-made croutons. This was surprisingly good, refreshing, acidic, and crisp, balanced perfectly with the pinot gris.  Next was one of my favorite dishes of the night. La langoustine was delightful in its simplicity, two langoustine on the shell with citrus reduction and fennel salad. Again, perfect pairing with the wine. I was slightly disappointed to not get the langoustine wrapped in the wonton wrapper I had seen on many Yelp reviews, but that's the difference between a tasting menu and a la carte, I guess. The langoustine was slightly hard to get out of the shell, but the flavors were rich and decadent throughout, the richness of the langoustine tempered perfectly by the light fennel salad.  A beautiful, earthy Morgon accompanied the next course: the mushroom tart. Again, I had a tough time with the texture on a personal level; mushrooms have never been my thing. That said, i might have been made a believer by this. The porcini mushrooms were slightly too chewy, and a bit salty, but the foie gras and the mushroom sauce were both amazing.  Surprisingly enough, the earthy Morgon stayed on the table for le homard- lobster with coconut foam and a malabar pepper sauce. Again, flavors I never would have thought to put together, but were explosively delicious when combined in my mouth. The earthy red cut through the pepper sauce perfectly, and the lobster and coconut foam were sublime. My one regret is that the lobster was overcooked and tough to cut.  Patrick was kind enough to allow me to substitute my entree. I had my heart set on La Caille- the foie gras stuffed quail. It was just as divine as the many reviews made it sound. Words dont truly do it justice. Hopefully the photos will convey some of the sheer culinary majesty. It was served with the legendary Joel Robuchon potatoes. So creamy. So buttery. So melt in your mouth delicious.   Time for the dessert courses. A sharp, tannic Sauternes was served with an exotic fruit mousse with passion fruit sorbet, followed by a pear mousse and sorbet with chocolate tuile. My stomach was groaning at this point, but I had to finish! Like the rest of the night, every bite of dessert was rich, fresh, and memorable.   There was some kind of massive error with the Mlife system that caused some delay in processing my room charge, which almost made me late for a show, but I can't fault a restaurant or food for technology issues.   As a final worthy mention, half the joy of this culinary experience is sitting at the counter top and watching your dishes being prepared. Its amazing to see an entire professional kitchen work seamlessly to put such art on a plate.  Overall, the entire night was truly once in a lifetime. Patrick and Max took great care of me, and in True Michelin fashion, used utensils were taken away with every course, dropped napkins replaced before you could think to do it yourself. Brian's recommendations and pairings for the wine were inspired. Anyone with an appreciation for fine dining should treat themselves to this at least once in their Vegas ventures. An immersive culinary experience that is overlooked at your own regret.

7EdM2Hx3YWNv1xaZ6cW7AQ.text: We went to L'Atelier on 9/12/19 for our anniversary dinner, this has been a bucket list experience for both of us. The service was everything you would expect, courteous, attentive and on top of every need before you even knew you needed it. The decor and seating was amazing, being able to watch the kitchen was fascinating. The food and cocktails were, I don't even know how to describe them, all I know is I can still close my eyes and taste the dishes in my memories and I will for a long time. We both had the seasonal tasting menu with the steak option, wow!!.   The only drawback was a diner and his guest in the corner that was obviously very intoxicated and loud, he was using extremely vulgar language and expletives, shouting for waitstaff and demanding attention and abusing his poor guest. I really wish this could have been addressed as it really took away from the beginning of our experience, we were eventually offered a table away from him which was nice but then we missed seeing the kitchen action, I feel if you are spending that much on a meal the ambiance should be better regulated if possible and that this could have been controlled as it was greatly out of hand by the time we were seated. Even seating us at a different area at the bar would have been acceptable as there were seats.   Overall this was an amazing once in a lifetime experience for me that I am saving to repeat, I recommend it highly to anyone looking for something different to try, you will not regret it.

LdlFIbCNZVYq6-1iK18Ltw.text: For our anniversary dinner, my husband and I decided to grab an early dinner at L'Atelier de Joel Robuchon to ensure we wouldn't miss our late evening flight back home from Vegas.  We arrived right at our reservation time, and we were seated immediately at the counter so we could watch the kitchen do its magic.  Food: My husband and I chose to do the Pre-Theatre menu which included an appetizer, entree, and dessert.   Pureed Beets Amuse Bouche - This was delicious. It was a bright color and a little sweet.  Scallops Appetizer - This was good, but the scallops were sliced thinly and I do prefer the whole piece.  Stuffed Salmon Entree - I wasn't thrilled with the tapenade filling, but I enjoyed the salmon portion. The entree also came with a side of Joel Robuchon's famous potatoes, and it was absolutely heavenly.   Chocolate Mousse Dessert - Perfect for the chocolate lover that I am.  My husband had the gazpacho, the wagyu steak (supplemental cost), and the passion fruit mousse cake. He enjoyed his meal, but he doesn't feel like it was worth the cost.   Service: The service began very well, as we were the first people to be seated. We were checked up on regularly and asked how everything was. However, when we were done with our dessert, our waiter was quite busy with other tables that it took awhile for us to receive our check. We didn't mind too much.  The restaurant also gave us a trio of mini desserts since we were celebrating our anniversary, which is always a nice sentiment!   TL;DR - A decent more upscale restaurant that can get pretty pricey. Would definitely recommend sitting at the counter to watch the kitchen work!

Oodtlt7SaOaJ1mzNajuUvA.text: A few of us girls took a trip to Vegas for our birthdays. We had a reservation at a different restaurant but when we got there the restaurant was shut down temporarily due to power outage! So last minute, we decided to dine at L'Atelier de Joel Robuchon.  Since it was a Tuesday night we were able to get seats at the bar overlooking all the action in the kitchen!  Yay for us!   Service was excellent throughout the dinner service, and it was fun to see what other people were eating too!   I've been to Joel Robuchon in NYC a long time ago, but this was more of a casual vibe with a relaxed atmosphere.  Whenever I'm in a higher end restaurant, I always start judging by their bread service and butter.  Their breads were undeniably pretty and delicious but I just wish they were served warm. I'm not keen on cold breads.   Since we ordered from the seasonal discovery menu, we all ate the same thing.  1. L'amuse-bouche - foie gras parfait with port wine reduction and parmesan emulsion. Amazing!  2. Le Thon - Japanese tuna tartare with avocado and virgin olive oil. The tartare was fresh and flavor was great but was on a salty side.  3. Les tomates - Chilled tomato gazpacho served with spiced burrata cheese, croutons and fleur de sel. I am normally not a gazpacho fan, but this one was superb!  4. La Langoustine - seared langoustine, citrus reduction, fennel salad.  Langoustine flesh was sweet, succulent, and I really wanted more of this!  5. Les champignons - mushroom tart with baby onions and seared foie gras. Again this was on a salty side for us. Not inedible but salty.  6. Le homard du maine - roasted maine lobster in Malabar pepper sauce with spinach. Delicious and no complaints here!  7. La volaille - duo of duck foie gras and free range chicken with caramelized Belgian endives. By this time we were getting full already and were wondering how on earth some people could eat the other option of the wagyu beef ribeye, because the ribeyes that were going out were humongous! LOL  8. Le tourbillon exotique - exotic fruit mousse, cookie sable, passionatta sorbet. Simply delicious!  9. La poire William - pear mousse and sorbet, chocolate cookie tuile. Wow! Just look at that lace work on the tuile. So elegant and delicious!  Overall, excellent restaurant and a good experience.  They were super generous with their complimentary dessert as well since it was our birthday dinner.  Superb service and our waiter was funny too!  If not for the couple of dishes being too salty, I'd given them 5 stars.

NDlWTDChqsqD_rVQTR66Uw.text: #700 I had the opportunity of coming here, brought by my best friend, in celebration of my birthday. All i was told is I had dinner with her that night, and to dress business casual. I didn't know where we were going until maybe 30 minutes before our reservation while her husband was driving us.   L'Atelier de Joel Robuchon was once a 1 Michelin star recipient. This was "officially" my first fine dining Michelin experience.  We were sat near the entrance in a corner spot where two people flanked each side. This is the first time i've seen a dark themed kitchen but it looked AMAZING ! Red accents w/ spotlights at specific areas with bright colors. It was "dark" but not dark at the same time.   Being a once Michelin starred restaurant, the service, of course, was amazing. VERY attentive staff. Water is constantly being refilled. Utensils replaced and area wiped after each course. Napkin refolded when customer leaves seat. Bread basket gets replaced if some bread is missing (MINDBLOWN#1). Basket consisted of 3 types including a mini-baguette, a croissant-like round roll, and a sourdough-like mini bread. My only complaint is the bread was not warm. I believe this bread would be much yummier if it was heated up a bit.   We all opt'ed for the "$108 Menu A" which includes an Amuse-Bouche, 2 Entrees au Choix (Appetizers), 1 Plats au Choix (Main Course), 1 Dessert.  The Amuse-Bouche consisted of a parmigiano reggiano foam on top, port wine reduction in the middle, and foie gras mousse on the bottom. Savory foam with a creamy/rich mousse, cut through with the reduction. OMG ! (MB#2) if this is how this dinner is going to go, i'm in trouble LOL ! A lot of times, i'm saddened by the small amount given in an amuse-bouche, even if it's supposed to be like a "mouth wetter". This time, this "small" amount packed a PUNCH ! WOW !   "Les Langoustine" (+$15) is a crispy langoustine fritter w/ basil pesto  One of their signature dishes (didn't know). Love seafood. Langoustine is always something that's like "rare" in terms of shrimp (to me anyway). Simple dish. Fresh/sweet langoustine wrapped with a basil leaf, wrapped with a thin crispy shell. Basil pesto light in flavor.   "Le Mais" is a polenta galette, farm fresh hen egg w/ shaved Iberico ham  Polenta "cake" lightly fried but nice and creamy in the middle topped with a rich, hen egg yolk. Shaved Iberico ham and parmigiano reggiano deliciousness. The flavor of the ham is so strong, it cuts through EVERYTHING! Rich egg yolk, arugula, parmigiano reggiano doesn't stop its flavor from taking over !    "Le Caille" (+$15) is a caramelized quail filled w/ foie gras served with potato puree  OMG ! (this is another signature dish) HOLY CRAP ! The caramelization of the quail is out of this world (MIND BLOWN #3). The foie gras is filled inside the quail breast (MB #4). The flavor of the quail and everything together (MB #5). Despite the "small" portion of the breast and leg "quarters". I was savoring this as SLOW AS I COULD ! Oh my the flavors were SO GOOD. With each chew, more bursts of flavor go into your mouth ! mMm ! Side of their signature potato puree was nice and smooth.   "Le Chocolate" is a Chocolate sensation, "cremeux" Araguani, and Oreo cookie crumbs  Simple looking chocolate dessert. The rich, smooth chocolate was the "coolest" aspect of this dish. The "surrounding area" looks like melted ice cream but was like a light cream. Great for chocolate lovers !   In addition, this is what my friend's had and i saw/tried  "Le Saint Jacques" is thin slices of scallops marinated in lemon and fresh radish salad   B-E-A-UTIFUL plating. Very refreshing, simple. Scallops fresh and super tender. Lemon and radish is bright and fresh !   "Le Crabe Royal" (+$15) is a King crab and ruby grapefruit salad prepared w/ a spiced avocado  Very sweet and fresh tasting king crab.   "Les Spaghettis" is a wild mushroom spaghetti "rustichella" pasta  Creamy, earthy pasta i almost wanna say it was made with bucatini instead of spaghetti. It was a thicker pasta than spaghetti but i was unsure if there was a hollow tube in the middle. I can't tell what all the mushrooms used were but one has got to be Chanterelle's. The mushrooms were salty and juicy, releasing their earthy mushroom flavor into the creamy white sauce. Simple but delicious. (MINDBLOWN #6)  "Le Veau" is confit veal breast honey glazed w/ a zucchini saltimbocca  Never had veal breast but we think it looked like pork belly or maybe a boneless country style rib. Light in flavor. Nice glaze. The saltimbocca flavor wise reminded us of a Chinese minced meat "cake"   "L'ananas" consists of exotic pineapple, aged rum granite and pabana foam  Light foam w/ diced "exotic" pineapple on the bottom. Definitely presented beautifully and tasted refreshing !   Overall, an AMAZING experience. Highly recommended to try at least ONCE. I was lucky to have been brought here. I wouldn't know when I would have came here myself. Definitely a MEMORABLE experience!

97vRgI2mOiRBk_YQWeDj7A.text: We dined fairly early on a Thursday evening. Party of two, seated at counter with the kitchen view. There was a lot of very rich food. I didn't enjoy the amuse bouche but I'm not a huge fan of fois gras. The king crab salad and the wagyu rib eye were my favorites. I honestly didn't feel very well as we rolled out of there two hours later. Too much, too rich. I can't imagine making it through the big tasting menu. We each had the amuse, two apps, one entree, and dessert plus a lovely bottle of Bordeaux. Dinner didn't quite break the bank coming in around $525. We checked a box but I don't know that we will venture in again. Well worth the experience though.

YWVyePDWUDFwJritkeVrtA.text: I am reviewing this as a high(er) end venue.  While it is the *more* casual sister restaurant to the next door Robuchon, it still bears itself as a semi-formal venue of high quality.  Overall: 3 stars Atmosphere: 3 stars Food/wine: 4.5 stars Service: 1.5 stars  Atmosphere: A little cramped...  The low tables looked more comfortable than the high top we sat at.  The counter also looked cramped but not terrible.  It was well lit and ventilated.  Food/wine: We had the tasting menu plus two appetizers. The apps (jamon iberica and the diced tomato toast dish) were tasty.  A general comment on the wine pairings.  Two of us did the regular and one did the premium wine pairing.  Both were fantastic.  The amuse bouche was amazing!  Foie gras parfait with port wine reduction and Parmesan emulsion.  Course 1 Le Thon, Japanese tuna tartare with avocado and virgin olive oil.  I chose to add the caviar supplement and it was 100% the right call.  My friends did not and without the caviar the dish is much plainer.  Course 2 Les Tomates, chilled tomato gazpacho served with spiced burrata cheese, croutons, and fleur de sel.  Well balanced.  Course 3 La Lagoustino, seared lagoustine, citrus reduction, and fennel salad.  Decent.  Course 4 Les Champignons, mushroom tart with baby onions and seared foie gras.  This was our first issue with the actual food.  My serving had NO foie gras.  My friends had foie gras in their serving and enjoyed the dish immensely.  Mine was unbalanced.  Course 5 Le Homard du Maine, toasted Maine lobster in Malabar pepper sauce with spinach.  The sauce was phenomenal!  Course 6 was a choice.  I had La Volaille, duo of duck foie gras and free range chicken with caramelized Belgium endives.  It was the best course, BY FAR, of any we had.  I allowed my friends to try it and agreed.  Which is relevant because they had the supplement choice; Le Contre-Filet, "Kagoshima" Wagyu beef ribeye with bone marrow topping.  The MOST disappointing dish of the night.  The chef's recommendation was medium-rare; so despite thinking medium would be better for that cut, my friends ordered in medium-rare.  It arrived well done... over done.  And the topping was lacking in flavor.  Both options came with whipped butter potatoes which were fantastic... except one serving was delivered to my friend ice cold and had to be replaced.  Course 7 Le Tourbillon Exotique, exotic fruit mousse, cookie sable, and passionatta sorbet.  A nice complement to the previous.  Course 8 La Poire William, pear mousse and sorbet, and chocolate cookie guile.  Very nice ending course.  In summary, if the foie gras wasn't missing, the wagyu wasn't overdone, and one of the potatoes wasn't cold, then I would have given 5 stars for the food/wine.  Service: The issues were persistent throughout.  The first issue was that by course two we were curious about the slow pace.  When we asked the waiter, very politely, to explain the pacing to us, we were treated to a condescending response.  He insinuated that we were not only incorrect, but that any delay was clearly due to us leaving the table at times.  If he had been paying attention he would have noted we NEVER left the table UNTIL that very moment when one person went to the restroom BECAUSE it was taking so long for our food to arrive.  Upon returning with the next course he again stated that the kitchen would 'make an exception' and bring out dishes even when we 'weren't seated'.  Unbelievably rude when we were nothing but polite and simply trying to provide feedback.  Also we had to ask for more water multiple times all night.  As a follow-up, we were proven correct when we noticed that the party of three sat next to us, who began their tasting menu a full hour after us, received the desert courses at the same time that we did.  One of the wines listed on the premium wine pairing menu came out incorrectly. It was listed incorrectly on the menu, under a different name. This in and of itself is an understandable error and simply needs to be corrected on the menu... since the wine listed does not actually exist. But in addition the year listed must have ran out and they brought out a newer vintage of the wine... With no explanation. When you are expecting a particular wine and year, it is customary for the sommelier to explain any substitution that is occurring.  When we mentioned the issues with the main course to the staff, we received virtually no response. When a customer provides negative feedback, the expectation is that there will be some acknowledgment.  All in all these service issues were not catastrophic, but when taken in total they represent service far below the expectation for a venue of this class. They were certainly aware that we were not having an optimal experience. And yet no manager or chef came out to ask us for feedback or to apologize or make any acknowledgment of the issues.  In summary, for a high end tasting chef's menu experience, I would recommend going elsewhere.

b-Lk10zot1isbrvlYLiqEA.text: I mean, its a full blown top notch cuisine experience. Its not just the food.  However, I think everybody should come here at least once in their life. Just to have that experience.   Tasting things that are prepared not to fill your belly, but your heart and soul. Its grandiose! Everything from the servers, the view of the kitchen,  and every plate.  Go for it!!

4jywg2blowd0sTUgBxYUtA.text: My visit dates back to a year or so, so this review is definitely long overdue. Nevertheless, my experience at this establishment remains so clear in my mind that I HAD to share my experience in the hopes of convincing those who are still 'undecided' about visiting this place to just go and try it!   FYI- I had no idea who Joel Robuchon is until I visited this place and researched him. Hence, you can be rest assured that I wasn't attracted to this place just because it bears the name of a star chef.  Ambiance  Love it! You can obviously see that the color red is emphasized all around. I believe L'atelier in Japan (Roppongi Hills) has a similar layout of the restaurant. I really like the consistency in the color theme. The space is smaller than I expected and I think there's a good chance that most people will be seated at the bar table which is more fun anyway. :)  Food This was my very first time trying molecular gastronomy and it truly opened up a door to a whole new world. It's just nothing like anything you've ever experienced. It really highlights the flavor of every ingredient being used in every dish. This is truly an eye opening experience for those who of us who are used to a 'jumble' of flavors only to be topped by heavy seasoning of some type that's often overwhelms the palate.   Service Service was great. Being seated at the bar table, there really wasn't a lot of interaction with the server as the food was being handed to us as they come. It was good!  Price & Joel Robuchon So... I opted for menu A with a glass or two of wine. I don't remember what I paid but I think it was $250ish (this was a year or two ago). Seeing that Joel Robuchon was right next door, my friend and I naturally started talking about JR and how that place will compare to this one. Given the hefty price tag (he told me to expect the bill to be over $1K if getting drinks and this is when degustation was still $345, now that's been increased to $455), I'd strongly recommend starting at this place first.   Now that I've been to JR, my recommendation remains the same. I think L'atelier is perfect to start off your JR adventure and to see if you really enjoy this type of cuisine without breaking bank. I think the quality of food is not that different. The main difference is that JR uses fancier, delicacies which  l will naturally drive up the price and they serve more food (16-course meal spread out in 6 services). I think L'atelier is a mini version or a trial version to see if you want to pursue the 'full-on' experience that JR has to offer. And once you decide that it's a green light, then you should definitely pay a visit to the neighbor next door!

65JopPl4cRRwZ_W0TYqAfA.text: L'ATELIER de Joel Robuchon is a *casual but high end excibition tapas (meaning small plate) restaurant located in the MGM on the Las Vegas Strip. The late chef Joel Robuchon was known as chef of the century and also was the most starred Michelin chef in the world. (*casual but you must be dressed business casual and shorts are not allowed)  This is a reservation only restaurant. They seat you around a high top counter to view the kitchen. I don't know what you have to do or how much money you have to lose to get seated at one of the few tables. You order ala carte or off one of the tasting menus. Most plates are small.  They start you off with an amuse bouche that has been a foie gras shooter with parmesan foam for the last few years but will give you a vegetarian amuse bouche if you ask. They also give you a basket of amazing breads with French Butter.  I usually get the three course tasting menu and find that it is enough for me. But this year they changed the menu and now the three course is now the early bird special ($85. subject to change) and is only offer now from 5pm-6pm.  Between the two of us we ordered Eggplant/Avocado Fondant w/turmeric croutons Polenta, Egg, Iberico Ham Halibut Flakes, fingerling Robuchon Potatoes Short Rib, Vegetables Robuchon Potatoes Les Tartes  Nearly everything was extraordinary. Most things don't just knock it out of the park...They knock it out of the galaxy.  The Master is gone but his magic remains.

74PZ0O4UfZ-YfZY4wlO2jw.text: I had high expectation for this French restaurant that marked by the famous Joel Robuchon. First bad impression is the bread, it's very disappointing that they don't even serve a fresh baked bread. I mean at least serve a real good French croissant and baguette. They were very dry and the butter taste like store brought.   Food taste good but not memorable for the price we paid. I got halibut but it's dry and seem over cooked so I asked the server if this right? The chef send the plate back to me untouched, didn't even cut through it and said that how it should be. My point here is that he just looked at it and supposed to know that it's perfect the way it should be? How could he not considering a person's opinion and just said it's right? 3 of us tasted it and agreed that it's dry and over cooked. I think it's rude!   The decoration and setting is really nice but that's about it! For the price you're paying, there're way better places in Vegas to get better food and service.

H4r78xJL0HIKTT8CSnFbxA.text: I have been dying to eat here and man they did not disappoint!  They offered different meal options, from tasting menu, to a la carte. Our waiter portioned our meal for us with what we said we liked from the menu.   We went with menu with 2 appetizers and 1 entree with dessert.   There's nothing better than when the waiter brings you piping hot bread and butter! And I was quite disappointed that they gave us a cold bread basket... sigh. I had one croissant and didn't care for the rest.   Foie gras parfait: Amazing!!! Melt in your mouth. So good I took my boyfriend's and ate his too. Absolutely phenomenal!!   Foie gras and fruit:  Luxuriously delicious!!    King crab and grapefruit salad:  Love the char on the romaine. I couldn't get enough of the chunks of king crab. The citrus and avocado really balanced each other.   Seabass carpaccio: So light and refreshing.   Langoustine fritters: Fried to perfection.  Dover sole: Wasn't that impressed with the flavors, but was very impressed with how the server deboned the fish in front of us. He did it with so much finesse, and he gets extra points for shooting me extra butter sauce.  Wagyu beef ribeye and potato puree:  Who doesn't love wagyu?! Cooked rare to our liking and magic in your mouth potato puree. So rich and velvety.   Dessert: Variety tarts and chocolate suduction... Maybe I was extra full, but dessert wasn't really anything to be wowed about. I tasted each tart and was done. My boyfriend on the other hand says his dessert was the best part.

1RQVuLQ6JwLtWj9dtc6nPQ.text: "L'Atelier" is one of the most beautiful words I have heard spoken, which is fitting because the experience I had here is comfortably within my lifetime top ten.  The tasting menu at the workshop is masterful and the service is airtight. It's a splurge but is presented and paced in a way that even the most inexperienced guest can have a memorable night.

oNEQ_kyhL6DF4PoBubCgsw.text: Tasty food, great presentation and amazing service! Highly recommend this place! It's worth the price!

unRfWNUOrze9Dda0nUNgAA.text: #142 Every bite - from the bread basket to the dessert - was spectacular! Incredibly knowledgeable wait staff. Wine pairing recommendations were impeccable. Sit at the bar for a clear view of all the work it takes to execute this level of culinary perfection.

3RdTKlstnsjdAg7mv3YPyQ.text: This is honestly my favorite compared to Joel Robuchon!   The atmosphere is much more casual and reservations are easy to make off opentable.  They have many tasting menu options, if you go early you can get the pre theater which is perfect portion and priced! You can make it to a show afterwards too.   I love the open kitchen concept, where you can watch all the action, like an episode of Chef's Table.   The food is spot on, their signature is the creamy mash potatoes which is so fluffy and decadent, it makes you guilty for finishing it, but you cant help it.

jafZnZVWtT-QfPtXxMMz_A.text: One of the best meals I've ever had!  The butter and bread and of course the mashed potatoes are legendary, it is to die for. I still dream of it.   The interior is so beautiful, staff are so attentive and impressed with how they explain your food.  The open kitchen is very entertaining  to watch. Stay in the counter if you can.   Portions were small but that's how it should be and that's how I like it. Definitely worth every $$$   Highly recommend when in Vegas. More like, do NOT miss this experience.

d5gNZ_HIBoxP3nAAzSCgsA.text: We came for the early 3 course pre-theater menu between 5-6 PM. By the time you add on cocktails, it will be over $100 per person for dinner.   Some reviewers expect the quality to be like Joel Robuchon next door. But JR is a 3 star vs. LAJR is a 1 Star Michelin.  The food here and presentation is very good. We were very happy with our meals Staff was attentive, not obtrusive but a bit formal.   The restaurant was designed like a sushi bar and there are limited seating at tables for larger groups if 6 or more.  It does make it easier for the staff to bring you food.    For unclear reasons, I ended up getting served an additional crab salad on top of my 3 course prix  fixe menu which I didn't order. She placed the dish in front of me and when I asked about my halibut entree, she said it was coming. I got the additional charge of $16 for the salad which was very good but it would be wise to question the food if you didn't order it.  Some of the wait staff speak French as their 1st language and it was hard to understand.  at times.   I don't recall the waiter who took our orders reading back our orders to us.

6hocp0tiIiWWH8ZIzXZhOg.text: Here is the 3-1-1:   Food: Selected as chef of the decade a couple of years ago, Joel Robuchon still continues to maintain the high tone, creative and decadent dishes at a price point that makes the value even better. For starters the salmon carpaccio with black pepper and micro greens was refreshing and blast of flavor to begin the culinary journey. The second small plate of poached oysters in butter with crushed red pepper to sprinkle was one of the best small bites of the evening as the combination of richness and spice is a must have. The seafood journey continues with seared bass, dover sole and poached lobster with champagne foam were all spectacular in their own right and with the signature whipped potatoes with infinity butter, it does not get any better. The menus continue to change so each time you go it will definitely be a new experience.  Service: Sitting at the bar and watching the action in the kitchen makes this a dinner & Vegas show in one place.  Though the place is full and dishes are coming out at a fast clip they make you feel special as they explain each dish and check on you to make sure everything is perfect.  Ambiance: Elegant, decadent and exciting. Fine dining with a hip vibe.

2v3JUpaetwXn74Sv-aI-Eg.text: I found myself very much impressed with L'Atelier's nine course tasting menu for $159 per person.  We were seated at the counter where we got to enjoy the "show," watching the chefs prepare each and every dish.  I've always appreciated fine dining, but watching the meticulous details that went into every single dish made me appreciate it that much more!  * Course 1 - The Amuse Bouche, a Foie Gras Parfait, was a lovely way to begin our adventure.  I don't really like Foie Gras, but in the parfait form, I actually liked it.  *   Course 2 - Snapper Tartar - This was a lovely way to whet the appetite further, especially after the rich taste of the Foie Gras Parfait.  It was light and refreshing.  *  Course 3 - Poached Oysters - I've never really tried oysters, raw or poached, but I decided to try it here, since they looked so appetizing.  I ate two and gave the third one to the husband since he LOVED this dish so very much.  I thought it was a bit salty and didn't really care for it all that much.  Maybe it's an acquired taste that I have yet to acquire.  *  Course 4 - Maine Lobster in a spicy broth - This was delicious.  The lobster was perfectly cooked, and not rubbery.  My only complaint is that it was so small!  *  Course 5 - White Onion Tart with Quail Egg - This was my favorite dish of the whole evening.  The tartlette was perfectly crisp, and the fried Quail Egg (which I had never tried before) complemented it perfectly.  Delicious!  I think I could have eaten about ten of these.  *  Course 6 - Monkfish Cheek - Very good.  The texture seemed almost like lobster and if no one had told me it was Monkfish Cheek, I would have thought it was lobster.  *  Course 7 - Veal Flank Steak - Perfectly cooked and delicious.  The husband went with the Duck stuffed with Foie Gras option that he immensely enjoyed.  I liked my Veal Flank Steak served with the best tasting mashed potatoes I've ever had... and I'm not really a lover of mashed potatoes, but this was quite divine.  The husband's duck came with the mashed potatoes as well.  *  Course 8 - Caramel Panacotta - Very delicious, and not too sweet, which I liked.  *  Course 9 - Raspberries with Chocolate Cake pieces - This was more decadent than the first dessert, but combined with the raspberries and the sauce that accompanied it, it was perfect.  The tasting menu also came with coffee, espresso, a latte or cappuccino with dessert.  The Latte I had here was perfect.  SO good, and was the perfect way to end a perfect meal.  I've been to several Michilin rated restaurants (Le Cirque, Picasso, Providence, Melisse), and L'Atelier fits the category for its fine cuisine.  The main difference that I really liked was that L'Atelier was not as stuffy as the others I've tried.  Sitting at the counter gave it a more casual feeling, kind of like sitting at the sushi bar.  The whole meal took a whopping 2.5 hours, but hey - we got dinner and a show, all in one - so I'd say it was all worth it!

gM5GXERID0ZrZ9mWKmdu6g.text: L'Atelier is one of my favorite restaurants of all time. My boyfriend and I go here almost every time we are in Vegas which is about 5 times a year and we have also been to the same L'Atelier in Paris as well. Every time we come here it feels like a new experience. The ambiance is great but not overly formal, and of course the food is always exceptional. We usually go a la cart but sometimes we do the prix fix menu. The mashed potatoes are LIFE CHANGING and the bread basket is also great. It is completely worth the money and experience, and is money better spent than seeing a Vegas show. Realistically only please go if you are willing to spend the money and love french food and dining experiences.

Jj10zNDEpB0_Pl4YUfy_Pg.text: I am a very lucky man! I have had some amazing meals in my life and my recent dinner at L'Atelier de Joel Robuchon was one of the best ever!  From the moment I arrived I was made to feel important and comfortable by the staff.  The restaurant itself is beautiful, elegant and modern.  I wanted to eat at the counter so I could watch the action in the open kitchen, but sadly it is not wheelchair accessible.  I am pointing this out for the benefit of my fellow yelpers, but I am not factoring it into my Star allotment.  Now onto the food.  Amuse-Foie Gras Parfait Port and Parmesan Foam Wonderful combination of richness,sweetness and saltiness.  1st Course-Langoustine Carpaccio with roasted Poppy Seed Dressing and Espelete Pepper. Light and Clean with nice acidity from the lemon in the dressing and a nice note of heat from the pepper.  2nd Course-Poached Baby Kussi Oysters with Echire Butter. I am not an Oyster fan and thought about asking for A substitution.  I am really glad I didn't.  The Oysters were mildly sweet and the combination of their briny juices , butter and chives was so good I drank it right from their shells when I finished the Oysters themselves.  3rd Course-Scallop with Seaweed Butter and Curried Cauliflower. Perfectly cooked Scallop with nicely caramelized crust and sweet, tender flesh.  The Cauliflower was interestingly different.  It  was served chilled and almost mashed, but still maintained its crisp texture.The curry did not overpower things at all and added a nice heat factor to the dish.  4th Course-Pumpkin Soup with Chestnuts. Very Rich and Creamy with a wonderful Pumpkin flavor.  The Chestnuts added a nice textural component to the Soup. I loved the fact that this soup was more savory than other pumpkin soups I've had, which are usually way to sweet for me.  5th Course-Steamed Seabass with Spicy confit peppers. My most straight forward dish of the evening, but beautiful in its simplicity! The fish melted in my mouth and the confit added just the right amount of seasoning. Before this course I had mentioned to one of the myriad of staff who attended to my every need during my meal, that I was hoping that one of my dishes would have Potatoes Robuchon with it.  Lo and behold, a small crock of the "Holy Grail" of mashed potatoes appeared as a side with the Bass.  6th Course-Foie Gras Stuffed Quail with Truffle Mashed Potatoes. Crispy skin, tender meat and the rich Foie worked wonders together!  Served with more of those unforgettable potatoes.  This time decadently studded with black truffles.  WOW!  7th Course-Lychee Panna Cotta with Mango, Macadamia Nuts and Coconut Sorbet. This was amazing. like a trip to Hawaii on a plate  8th Course-Green Apple Sorbet with Calvados Sabayon and Citrus Custard. Tasted like eating a fresh apple right off the tree!  The Citrus Custard added a nice acidic note to the dish.  9th Course-Tart Tasting  Five small bites that were all good, but my favorite was the Chocolate Cinnamon.  Before my meal I mentioned to the Sommelier that I didn't think I could handle a wine with every course, since I had several other drinks earlier that day (It is Vegas after all!). He was very helpful, and selected three wonderful glasses that he spaced out through my meal.  My night at L'Atelier was amazing and is definitely in my top five meals ever.

JObEjgOhd93sLRgep0oF_A.text: This is by far the best meal I ever had in Vegas. Maybe I haven't tried enough 3 michelin star restaurants to say that.  The whole dining experience was very impressive.  We overlooked the entire kitchen and enjoyed watching all the actions while tasting every bites of their creation.  It was a very calm and relaxing kitchen, you could tell that every dish was artfully prepared with great attention to details.    We tried out their 9 courses tasting menu, they were all creative and very very tasty.   1. Foie gras parfait with port wine and parmesan foam - Served in a little cup. A bit heavy for starter, but it did a great job satisfying my palate right at the beginning.  The port wine, cheese and foie gras all interplay really well together.   2. Celery mousse with wasabi, beef stew gelee and slices of foie gras - Another dish that served in a tiny cup.  Interesting combination of foie gras with wasabi, it was fantastic resulting in a spicy lingering finish to the dish.   3. Oysters with chives in lemon butter - Baby oysters poached in salted butter. Altogether 3 delicious small and plump fresh oysters swimming in butter, served hot.   4. Lobster with curry ginger sauce and edamme - Though I prefer a different type of sauce other than curry to go with lobster, the freshness and rich flavor of the lobster made this dish fantastic.   5. Quail egg on white onion tart with smoked bacon and asparagus The slight bitterness of asparagus balanced well by the smoked flavor of the bacon, the crispy tart and the quail egg made a good textural variation to the dish.    6. Monkfish cheek and baby leeks in buttery shellfish sauce with lime and ginger - The fish was so tender and fresh and balanced well with the buttery and astringent taste of the sauce.  7. Veal with tomato confit and shallot. Salsify root gratin with sheepmilk cheese, sweetbread and black truffle.  8. Champagne gelee topped with frozen raspberry mousse and rose scented meringue.  9. Baked chocolate ganache with aerated devil's food cake with fresh mint ice cream.  And we also ordered several must try on the regular menu.    1. Foie gras stuffed Quail with mashed potatoes - I love foie gras, but I don't think it went well with quail, it overpowered the delicious taste of the quail. The potatoes were mashed together with truffles and was incredibly tasty - Robuchon's signature item. It was creamy, rich, savory and very fine.   2. Lightly battered fried shrimp with basil in pesto sauce.  We were very impressed with the whole dining experience, not only with the food but also with the friendly interactive environment.

f1yl_izwpOBkF6InDorINg.text: Foie gras in burgers, aaahhhh soooo yummy! French serving at its finest! A must try!

Q9240DCZFy8NE0Wn67QC1g.text: Finally hit L'Atelier .   Tried the Fall Tasting Menu - $75 includes:   Amuse - Foie gras "shooter "- basically liquid foie gras with a parmesan foam - yummy !   Mozzarella / veggie stack - beautiful, amazing flavors in such a small dish ( actually, the serving was larger then i expected )   Langoustine Fritter w/ greens - nice flavor, but kinda boring compared to the Mozzarella.   Hanger steak with fried shallots - i gotta admit, the steak was a little on the chewy side, but the flavor was perfect   cheese plate w/ walnut raisin bread - 2 cow milk cheeses, a sheep's milk cheese and the 4th - i can't remember . very generous servings and the bread was a perfect compliment.   tart plate - 6 mini slices of tarts - a couple chocolate flavors, lemon, raspberry , orange, etc. Holy cow !! great dessert !!   coffee - OK   People - THIS IS A GREAT DEAL !!   pics posted
